info.game_comments:
2012 Power Players Week game 2.
From DAR Constitution Hall in Washington, D.C.

jeopardy_round: THE NEW YORK TIMES 21st CENTURY HEADLINES

(1, 1).clue: Locals in this Upstate New York City know it hosted the 1980 winter Olympics

(3, 1).clue: Genus Otus includes the screech type of this nocturnal bird

(5, 1).clue: The 5 movie ratings in the U.S. are NC-17, R, PG, PG-13 & this one

(6, 1).clue: In 2003 the headline read, "Davis Is Out, Schwarzenegger Is In by Big Margins in California" in this type of vote

(1, 2).clue: Folks on the Nevada border know this lake took its name from the Washoe word for "Big Water"

(3, 2).clue: The scarlet macaw, part of this talkative family, has beautiful plumage but an ugly squawk

(5, 2).clue: Including first, in which the heels are together, there are 5 basic foot positions in the classical type of this

(6, 2).clue: Howard Stern made the front page in 2004 after his "Rich Deal in Jump to" this type of radio

(1, 3).clue: Workers are way above average in ports such as Duluth on this Great Lake

(3, 3).clue: It's a bird, it's a crane, & it's named for its call

(5, 3).clue: Dolly Parton wrote, "Workin"' these hours, "what a way to make a livin"'

(1, 4).clue: People walk like Egyptians around this lake formed by the creation of the Aswan High Dam

(5, 4).clue: "The Five Ways", a work of 13th c. philosophy, lays out 5 proofs for the existence of this being

(1, 5).clue: U.N. office workers in Switzerland overlook this lake & have a view of the Alps

(5, 5).clue: Irene Hunt's novel "Across Five Aprils" takes place over the long years of this American conflict

(1, 1).clue: From 1951 to 1953 this future First Lady was an inquiring photographer for the Washington Times-Herald

(3, 1).clue: This author's all-star team, including Jack Ryan & John Clark, was back in his 2011 bestseller "Locked On"

(4, 1).clue: Sheryl Sandberg is the C.O.O. for this website born in a Harvard dorm; its users number over 10% of the world's people

(5, 1).clue: This object has 109 times the Earth's radius & is 93 million miles away from us

(6, 1).clue: From the Japanese, a 9 A.M. greeting:ohayo gozaimasu

(1, 2).clue: In 1983 she made history as the first American woman in space

(3, 2).clue: This Michael Crichton bestseller begins with a prologue, "The Bite of the Raptor"

(4, 2).clue: Once this woman, now the Duchess of Cambridge, wears something (such as nude stockings), sales soar

(5, 2).clue: In the 1910s this German physicist developed a "counter" to detect radiation

(6, 2).clue: From the Italian, what you want your room to have:la vista

(1, 3).clue: In 1920 this "Round Table" wit was fired as drama critic for Vanity Fair: they said her reviews were too harsh

(2, 3).clue: Sure, I'll do the impression: "Of all the gin joints in all the towns in all the world, she walks into mine"

(3, 3).clue: "The Da Vinci Code" was actually the second novel to feature symbologist Robert Langdon; this book was first

(4, 3).clue: (Warren Buffett reads the clue.)  More than 90% of my wealth will eventually go to philanthropy; in 2006 I pledged $30.7 billion to this man's foundation to help make that happen

(5, 3).clue: Making transfusions routine, biochemist Karl Landsteiner put together the A-B-O "typing" of this

(6, 3).clue: From the Spanish, our writers' favorite:la cerveza

(1, 4).clue: This late activist in her own right was inducted posthumously into the National Women's Hall of Fame in 2011

(2, 4).clue: Haley Joel Osment's "I see dead people"

(3, 4).clue: This Laura Hillenbrand best-seller is subtitled "A World War II Story of Survival, Resilience, and Redemption"

(4, 4).clue: In 1978 she hosted a Baltimore chat show called "People Are Talking"; her move to Chicago ended up working out

(6, 4).clue: From the French, a marine animal:la baleine

(1, 5).clue: Her resume includes president of the American Red Cross & U.S. senator from North Carolina

(2, 5).clue: In a 1982 charmer: "I'll be right here"

(3, 5).clue: His bestsellers include "Lincoln", "1876" & the less historical "Myra Breckinridge"

(4, 5).clue: The purported subject of "The Devil Wears Prada", this Vogue editor went to the film's premiere wearing Prada

(6, 5).clue: From the Hebrew, a period of time:yom

(0, 0).clue: Completed in 1959, it's been variously described as a snail, a concrete tornado, even a giant wedding cake
